expanded_description: Not all slopes are nice, whole numbers. Many real-world relationships involve fractional slopes—gentle hills instead of steep cliffs, slow changes instead of rapid ones. Graphing lines with fractional slopes requires careful attention to the rise and run, but the same principles apply: plot the y-intercept, then use the fraction as directions to find another point.

core_concept.principle: Fractional slopes are handled the same way as integer slopes: $m = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}$. The numerator tells how many units to move up or down, and the denominator tells how many units to move right. For example, slope $\frac{2}{3}$ means up 2, right 3; slope $-\frac{3}{4}$ means down 3, right 4.
core_concept.explanation: Think of fractional slopes as more precise directions. Instead of 'go up 2' (which would be slope 2), a slope of $\frac{2}{3}$ says 'go up 2 for every 3 you go right.' It's a gentler incline. The denominator is the horizontal distance you need to travel to see a whole-number rise. This makes fractional slopes excellent for modeling gradual changes.

image.alt: Comparison of slopes 2, 1, 1/2, 2/3 showing different steepness
image.caption: Figure 4.9.1: Fractional slopes produce gentler inclines.

sections.introduction: Fractional slopes represent rates of change that are not whole numbers. They are common in real life: speed of 0.5 miles per minute, cost of $\$0.75$ per item, temperature increase of 2.5° per hour.

introduction_image.alt: Number line showing fractional slopes between integers
introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.9.2: Fractional slopes fill the gaps between integer slopes.

key_concept.definition: A fractional slope $m = \frac{p}{q}$ means that for every $q$ units moved horizontally (run), the line moves $p$ units vertically (rise). The fraction can be positive or negative. The absolute value $|\frac{p}{q}|$ determines steepness: larger absolute value means steeper.
key_concept.context: Fractional slopes are essential for modeling real-world situations where rates are not whole numbers. They allow us to represent gradual changes precisely.

image.alt: Lines with slopes 1/2, 2/3, 3/4, 1/4 on same graph
image.caption: Figure 4.9.3: Various fractional slopes.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting Fractional Slopes

image.caption: Figure 4.9.4: What does each slope mean?

worked_examples.problem:
Interpret each fractional slope in words:
a) $m = \frac{2}{5}$
b) $m = -\frac{3}{4}$
c) $m = \frac{1}{3}$
d) $m = -\frac{5}{2}$

step_by_step.explanation: Positive slope means up; numerator = rise, denominator = run
step_by_step.calculation: Up 2 units for every 5 units right
Down 3 units for every 4 units right
Up 1 unit for every 3 units right

step_by_step.explanation: Steep negative slope (rise > run in absolute value)
step_by_step.calculation: Down 5 units for every 2 units right

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Up 2, right 5
b) Down 3, right 4
c) Up 1, right 3
d) Down 5, right 2
worked_examples.concept_applied: Fractional slopes: numerator = rise, denominator = run. Sign indicates direction.

sections.introduction: Graphing lines with fractional slopes follows the same process as integer slopes, but requires careful counting of the run.

introduction_image.alt: Graphing line with slope 2/3 from y-intercept
introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.9.6: Graphing a fractional slope.

key_concept.definition: To graph a line with fractional slope $m = \frac{p}{q}$: (1) Plot the y-intercept. (2) From that point, move right $q$ units. (3) Move up (if $p$ positive) or down (if $p$ negative) $p$ units. (4) Plot the new point. (5) Draw the line through both points.
key_concept.context: The key is to use the denominator as your horizontal move. This ensures you're moving a whole number of grid units, making the second point easy to plot accurately.

image.alt: Step-by-step: y-intercept, right q, up/down p
image.caption: Figure 4.9.7: Steps for graphing fractional slopes.

worked_examples.title: Graphing Lines with Fractional Slopes

step_by_step.explanation: Y-intercept at (0,1). Slope $\frac{2}{3}$: right 3, up 2 to (3,3).
Y-intercept at (0,2). Slope $-\frac{3}{4}$: right 4, down 3 to (4,-1).
Y-intercept at (0,-3). Slope $\frac{1}{2}$: right 2, up 1 to (2,-2).
Y-intercept at (0,4). Slope $-\frac{5}{2}$: right 2, down 5 to (2,-1).

worked_examples.concept_applied: For slope p/q, move right q, then up/down p from y-intercept.

worked_examples.title: Using Equivalent Fractions

image.alt: Multiple ways to plot same slope
image.caption: Figure 4.9.13: Different representations of slope 2/3.

worked_examples.problem: Graph $y = \frac{2}{3}x - 1$ using two different equivalent fractions for the slope.

step_by_step.explanation: Same slope, but now right 6, up 4 from (0,-1) to (6,3)
Both points (3,1) and (6,3) lie on same line

worked_examples.final_answer: Both methods produce points on the same line.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Equivalent fractions give the same slope; you can scale rise and run by the same factor.

process_flow.description: Plot the point $(0, b)$ on the y-axis.
From slope $m = \frac{p}{q}$, note rise = $p$, run = $q$. Sign of $p$ tells direction (positive = up, negative = down).
process_flow.mechanism: If slope is an integer, write as $\frac{m}{1}$.

image.alt: Slope fraction with rise and run labeled
image.caption: Figure 4.9.17: Step 2 - Identify rise and run.

process_flow.description: From y-intercept, move horizontally to the right by $q$ units.
process_flow.mechanism: Always move right for standard graphing (you can also move left by using negative run).

image.caption: Figure 4.9.18: Step 3 - Move right by run.

process_flow.description: From that position, move up if $p$ positive, down if $p$ negative.

image.alt: Moving up or down by rise
image.caption: Figure 4.9.19: Step 4 - Move vertically by rise.

process_flow.description: Connect the two points with a straight line, extending in both directions.

sections.introduction: Fractional slopes appear frequently in real-world situations where rates are not whole numbers.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.9.22: Fractional slopes in real life.

key_concept.definition: Real-world rates often come as fractions or decimals: speed 62.5 mph, cost $\$0.75$ per item, temperature change 2.5° per hour. These become fractional slopes when graphed. The denominator represents the time or quantity interval needed to see a whole-number change.
key_concept.context: Understanding fractional slopes allows us to model and interpret these common situations accurately.

worked_examples.title: Fuel Efficiency

image.caption: Figure 4.9.24: Gallons used over miles driven.

worked_examples.problem:
A car uses 1 gallon of gas every 25 miles. Let $g$ = gallons used and $d$ = miles driven.
a) What is the slope (gallons per mile)? Write as a fraction.
b) Write the equation relating gallons to miles, assuming starting with 0 gallons.
c) How many gallons are used after 150 miles?

step_by_step.explanation: 1 gallon per 25 miles means $\frac{1}{25}$ gallons per mile
Passes through origin (0 gallons at 0 miles)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Fractional slope represents rate (gallons per mile).

worked_examples.title: Cooking Temperature
worked_examples.problem:
An oven heats from room temperature (20°C) to 180°C in 8 minutes at a constant rate.
a) Find the heating rate in °C per minute as a fraction.
b) Write the temperature equation.
c) What is the temperature after 5 minutes?

step_by_step.calculation: $m = \frac{160}{8} = 20$°C/min (this is an integer, not a fraction)

step_by_step.explanation: Let's use a fractional example: heats from 20°C to 165°C in 10 minutes

worked_examples.final_answer: Fractional slopes model rates that aren't whole numbers.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world rates often simplify to fractions.

sections.introduction: Decimal slopes are another way to represent fractional rates. They can be converted to fractions for easier graphing.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.9.27: Decimal slopes convert to fractions.

key_concept.definition: A decimal slope like $m = 0.75$ can be written as a fraction $\frac{3}{4}$ for graphing. To convert, write the decimal as a fraction over the appropriate power of 10, then simplify. For example, $0.6 = \frac{6}{10} = \frac{3}{5}$, $1.25 = \frac{125}{100} = \frac{5}{4}$.
key_concept.context: Converting decimal slopes to fractions makes graphing easier because you work with whole-number rise and run. It also helps in understanding the meaning of the slope.

image.alt: Table of decimal to fraction conversions
image.caption: Figure 4.9.28: Converting decimals to fractions.

sections.introduction: Comparing fractional slopes helps us understand which lines are steeper, even when the fractions have different denominators.

key_concept.definition: To compare fractional slopes, compare their decimal equivalents or use cross-multiplication. For positive slopes, larger value means steeper. For negative slopes, more negative (smaller) means steeper. Remember to use absolute value for steepness comparison.
key_concept.context: Being able to compare fractional slopes helps in real-world decisions: which rate is faster? which price is cheaper per unit? which growth rate is greater?

worked_examples.title: Comparing Fractional Slopes
worked_examples.problem:
For each pair, determine which slope is steeper:
a) $\frac{2}{3}$ and $\frac{3}{4}$
b) $-\frac{5}{8}$ and $-\frac{2}{3}$
c) $\frac{4}{5}$ and $\frac{7}{10}$
d) $-\frac{3}{7}$ and $-\frac{2}{5}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare decimal equivalents or use cross-multiplication. For steepness, compare absolute values.

sections.introduction: Parallel lines have the same slope, even when that slope is a fraction. This is true for all slopes, fractional or integer.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.9.37: Parallel lines share the same fractional slope.

key_concept.definition: Two lines are parallel if and only if they have the same slope. This applies to fractional slopes as well. For example, $y = \frac{2}{3}x + 1$ and $y = \frac{2}{3}x - 4$ are parallel because they share slope $\frac{2}{3}$.
key_concept.context: Recognizing parallel lines with fractional slopes is important in geometry, design, and real-world applications like railroad tracks or architectural features.

image.alt: Two parallel lines with same fractional slope
image.caption: Figure 4.9.38: Parallel lines with slope 2/3.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Parallel Lines with Fractional Slopes
worked_examples.problem:
Determine which pairs of lines are parallel:
a) $y = \frac{2}{5}x + 3$ and $y = \frac{2}{5}x - 1$
b) $y = \frac{3}{4}x + 2$ and $y = \frac{4}{3}x + 2$
c) $y = -\frac{1}{2}x + 5$ and $y = -\frac{1}{2}x - 3$
d) $y = \frac{5}{3}x$ and $y = \frac{3}{5}x$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Parallel, b) Not parallel, c) Parallel, d) Not parallel
worked_examples.concept_applied: Parallel lines have identical slopes, regardless of whether slopes are fractions or integers.

sections.section_title: 4.9.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when graphing fractional slopes. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Using the numerator as run and denominator as rise.
characteristics: Confusing which part of fraction is horizontal movement
classifications.behavior: Line has reciprocal slope, wrong steepness.

image.caption: Figure 4.9.41: Error - swapping rise and run.

examples.explanation: Correct: right 3, up 2 (run = denominator, rise = numerator)

classifications.value: Treating negative slope as positive when moving.
characteristics: For $m = -\frac{3}{4}$, moving up instead of down
Forgetting that negative applies to numerator

image.alt: Correct vs incorrect direction for negative fractional slope
image.caption: Figure 4.9.42: Error - ignoring negative sign.

classifications.value: Not simplifying fractions or converting incorrectly.
characteristics: Converting 0.75 to $\frac{75}{100}$ but not simplifying to $\frac{3}{4}$
classifications.behavior: Correct slope but harder to graph, or wrong slope.

examples.process: Error: Converting 0.6 to $\frac{6}{10}$ but graphing as right 10, up 6 (correct but not simplified)

worked_examples.title: Correcting Fractional Slope Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student graphed $y = \frac{3}{4}x + 1$ by plotting (0,1) and then moving right 3, up 4 to (3,5). Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Student swapped rise and run: used numerator as run, denominator as rise
step_by_step.calculation: For slope $\frac{3}{4}$, rise = 3, run = 4, so should be right 4, up 3

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct second point is (4,4). Student swapped rise and run.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For slope p/q, rise = p, run = q. Move right q, up/down p.

image.caption: Figure 4.9.46: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills with fractional slopes to a variety of problems.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
1) Graph: a) $y = \frac{2}{5}x + 2$ b) $y = -\frac{3}{4}x - 1$ c) $y = \frac{1}{3}x$ d) $y = -\frac{5}{2}x + 3$
2) Convert to fractions and graph: $y = 0.8x - 2$
3) Which is steeper: $\frac{3}{8}$ or $\frac{2}{5}$?
4) Are $y = \frac{2}{3}x + 4$ and $y = \frac{4}{6}x - 1$ parallel?
5) Real-world: A car uses 1 gallon every 32 miles. Write equation for gallons used vs miles. How many gallons for 160 miles?

step_by_step.explanation: Through origin, slope 1/3: right 3, up 1 to (3,1)
0.8 = 4/5, so slope 4/5. Y-intercept (0,-2), right 5, up 4 to (5,2)

step_by_step.calculation: Same slope, so lines are parallel

worked_examples.final_answer:
1-2) Graphs as shown
3) $\frac{2}{5}$ is steeper
4) Yes, parallel
5) $g = \frac{1}{32}d$, 5 gallons

summary: Fractional slopes $m = \frac{p}{q}$ are handled the same way as integer slopes: the numerator $p$ tells the vertical change (rise), and the denominator $q$ tells the horizontal change (run). To graph, plot the y-intercept, then move right $q$ units and up/down $p$ units to find a second point. Positive slopes go up, negative slopes go down. Decimal slopes can be converted to fractions for easier graphing (e.g., $0.75 = \frac{3}{4}$, $0.6 = \frac{3}{5}$). Comparing fractional slopes involves comparing their decimal equivalents or using cross-multiplication; steeper slopes have larger absolute values. Parallel lines have identical slopes, whether fractional or integer. Real-world applications include fuel efficiency ($\frac{1}{32}$ gallons per mile), unit pricing ($\frac{3}{4}$ dollars per pound), and gradual temperature changes. Mastering fractional slopes expands our ability to model and graph a wider range of real-world relationships.
